canonical_explanation.text: A force is a push or pull acting on an object. Forces can change the speed, direction of motion, or shape of an object. Forces are broadly classified into contact forces (muscular force, friction) and non-contact forces (gravitational, magnetic, electrostatic). Pressure is the force acting per unit area. Pressure = Force / Area, and its SI unit is Pascal (Pa). For a given force, pressure increases when the area decreases and vice versa. Liquids exert pressure on the walls and bottom of the container, and this pressure increases with depth. Gases also exert pressure; the atmosphere exerts atmospheric pressure on all surfaces, which is demonstrated by many everyday phenomena.
rules: A force is a push or pull that can change the state of motion or shape of an object.
Contact forces require physical contact (e.g., muscular force, friction).
Non-contact forces act from a distance (e.g., gravity, magnetism, electrostatic force).
A force can make a stationary object move, stop a moving object, or change its direction.
Pressure = Force / Area; SI unit is Pascal (Pa).
For a given force, smaller area results in greater pressure.
Liquids exert pressure equally in all directions at the same depth.
Atmospheric pressure is the pressure exerted by the weight of air in the atmosphere.
Applications: sharp knives cut better (small area, high pressure), wide tyres reduce pressure on road.

questions.question_text: A force is defined as:

options.text: A push or pull acting on an object

questions.explanation_correct: A force is defined as a push or pull acting on an object. It can change the speed, direction, or shape of an object. Weight, speed, and size are different physical quantities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Weight (B) is a specific type of force due to gravity, not the general definition. Speed (C) measures how fast an object moves, and size (D) refers to dimensions — neither defines force. A force is any push or pull on an object.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT an effect of force?

options.text: Change in speed of an object
Change in shape of an object
Change in mass of an object

questions.explanation_correct: Force can change the speed, direction, or shape of an object, but it cannot change the mass of an object. Mass is an intrinsic property of matter and remains the same regardless of the force applied.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A force can change the speed (A), shape (B), and direction (D) of an object. However, mass (C) is a fundamental property of matter that does not change when a force is applied.

questions.question_text: What is the SI unit of force?
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of force is Newton (N), named after Sir Isaac Newton. One Newton is the force required to accelerate a mass of 1 kg by 1 m/s².
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kilogram (A) is the unit of mass, Pascal (C) is the unit of pressure, and Joule (D) is the unit of energy or work. The correct SI unit of force is Newton (N).

questions.question_text: When you kick a football, you apply a force that:
questions.explanation_correct: When you kick a football, the force applied changes its state of motion — the ball moves from rest or changes its speed and direction. This is one of the primary effects of force.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kicking a football does not change its colour (C) or mass (D). While the ball may deform slightly (A), the primary effect of kicking is changing its state of motion (B) — making it move or changing its speed and direction.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a contact force?
questions.explanation_correct: Muscular force is a contact force because it requires physical contact between the body applying the force and the object. For example, pushing a box or lifting a bag requires direct contact.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gravitational force (A), magnetic force (B), and electrostatic force (D) are all non-contact forces that can act on objects from a distance without physical contact. Only muscular force (C) requires direct contact.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a non-contact force?
questions.explanation_correct: Gravitational force is a non-contact force because it acts between two objects without any physical contact. The Earth pulls all objects towards itself due to gravity, even without touching them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Friction (A), muscular force (B), and normal force (D) all require physical contact between the surfaces or bodies involved. Gravitational force (C) acts from a distance without any contact.

questions.question_text: A magnet attracts an iron nail placed near it. The force involved is:
questions.explanation_correct: When a magnet attracts an iron nail without touching it, the force involved is magnetic force. This is a non-contact force that acts between a magnet and magnetic materials like iron.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Muscular force (A) requires direct physical contact. Frictional force (B) opposes motion between surfaces in contact. Gravitational force (D) is the attraction between any two masses. The specific force between a magnet and iron nail is magnetic force (C).

questions.question_text: A charged plastic comb attracts small pieces of paper. The type of force acting here is:
questions.explanation_correct: When a charged comb attracts paper pieces without touching them, it is an electrostatic force at work. This non-contact force occurs because the comb gets charged when rubbed and attracts uncharged objects like paper.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gravitational force (A) is too weak to explain this attraction at such small scales. Frictional force (C) requires surface contact. Muscular force (D) requires physical effort. The force here is electrostatic (B) — the charged comb exerts a non-contact force on the paper.

questions.question_text: Pressure is defined as:
questions.explanation_correct: Pressure is defined as force per unit area, which means Pressure = Force / Area. It tells us how much force is distributed over a given surface area.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pressure is not force multiplied by area (A), area divided by force (C), or force added to area (D). The correct formula is Pressure = Force / Area (B), measuring how concentrated a force is on a surface.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of pressure is:
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of pressure is Pascal (Pa), named after the French scientist Blaise Pascal. 1 Pascal = 1 Newton per square metre (1 Pa = 1 N/m²).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Newton (A) is the unit of force, Joule (B) is the unit of energy, and Watt (D) is the unit of power. The SI unit of pressure is Pascal (C), which equals 1 N/m².

questions.question_text: A force can only change the speed of an object but cannot change its shape.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. A force can change the speed, direction of motion, AND the shape of an object. For example, squeezing a rubber ball changes its shape.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false because a force has multiple effects — it can change speed, direction, and shape. Claiming it can only change speed is incorrect. Pressing clay or squeezing a sponge are examples where force changes shape.

questions.question_text: Friction is a non-contact force.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Friction is a contact force because it acts between two surfaces that are in physical contact with each other. It opposes the relative motion between surfaces that are touching.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Friction requires two surfaces to be in contact to act. It is therefore a contact force, not a non-contact force. Non-contact forces like gravity or magnetism can act without surfaces touching.

questions.question_text: A sharp knife cuts better than a blunt one because it exerts greater pressure on the surface.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. A sharp knife has a very thin edge, so the contact area is very small. Since Pressure = Force / Area, a smaller area for the same force results in greater pressure, making it easier to cut.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The sharp edge has a smaller surface area than a blunt edge. With the same force applied, the smaller area creates a higher pressure (P = F/A), which is why a sharp knife cuts more effectively.

questions.question_text: A force is a ___ or pull that can change the state of motion of an object.
questions.explanation_correct: A force is defined as a push or pull that acts on an object. It can change the speed, direction, or shape of the object it acts upon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'push'. Force is defined as a push or pull acting on an object. This is the fundamental definition of force in physics.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of pressure is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of pressure is Pascal (Pa), named after Blaise Pascal. 1 Pascal equals 1 Newton per square metre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Pascal'. Pressure is measured in Pascals (Pa) in the SI system. 1 Pa = 1 N/m².

questions.question_text: Pressure = Force / ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Pressure is calculated by dividing force by the area over which it acts. A smaller area with the same force leads to higher pressure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Area'. The formula for pressure is Pressure = Force / Area. This relationship explains why a pointed nail exerts more pressure than a flat surface.

questions.question_text: If the same force is applied on two surfaces, one with a large area and another with a small area, which surface will experience greater pressure?

options.text: Pressure does not depend on area

questions.explanation_correct: The surface with the smaller area will experience greater pressure. Since Pressure = Force / Area, when force is constant, pressure is inversely proportional to area. Smaller area means higher pressure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pressure is inversely proportional to area when force is constant. The surface with the larger area (A) will have less pressure. Both surfaces cannot have equal pressure (C) because their areas differ. Pressure does depend on area (D).

questions.question_text: Why do the straps of heavy school bags have broad pads on the shoulders?

options.text: To make the bag look attractive
To increase the weight of the bag
To reduce pressure on the shoulders by increasing the area
To increase pressure on the shoulders

questions.explanation_correct: Broad pads increase the area over which the force (weight of the bag) acts. Since Pressure = Force / Area, increasing the area reduces the pressure on the shoulders, making the bag more comfortable to carry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pads are not for appearance (A) or to increase weight (B). They do not increase pressure (D). Instead, broad pads reduce pressure (C) by spreading the force over a larger area, making the bag more comfortable.

questions.question_text: A block of wood exerts a force of 50 N on a table. If the area of contact is 0.5 m², what is the pressure exerted?
questions.explanation_correct: Pressure = Force / Area = 50 N / 0.5 m² = 100 Pa. The block exerts a pressure of 100 Pascals on the table.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the formula Pressure = Force / Area: P = 50 N / 0.5 m² = 100 Pa. The answers 25 Pa (A), 50 Pa (C), and 10 Pa (D) result from incorrect calculations.

questions.question_text: Liquids exert pressure on:

options.text: Only the bottom of the container
Only the walls of the container
The walls and bottom of the container

questions.explanation_correct: Liquids exert pressure on both the walls and the bottom of the container. This is because liquid particles are free to move and push against all surfaces they are in contact with.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Liquids do not exert pressure only on the bottom (A) or only on the walls (B). They exert pressure in all directions, including on the bottom and walls of the container (C). They do not push only on the top surface (D).

questions.question_text: As we go deeper in a liquid, the pressure:
questions.explanation_correct: The pressure in a liquid increases with depth because the weight of the liquid above increases as we go deeper. More liquid above means more force per unit area at greater depths.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Liquid pressure does not decrease (A), remain the same (B), or first increase then decrease (D) with depth. It continuously increases (C) because the column of liquid above becomes taller, adding more weight.

questions.question_text: Why are the walls of dams made thicker at the bottom?

options.text: To make the dam look attractive
Because water pressure increases with depth
Because the bottom needs more paint
To reduce the cost of construction

questions.explanation_correct: The walls of dams are thicker at the bottom because water pressure increases with depth. The bottom of the dam has to withstand much greater pressure from the water above, so it needs to be stronger and thicker.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The thicker bottom has nothing to do with appearance (A), paint (C), or cost reduction (D). It is designed to withstand the higher water pressure (B) at greater depths.

questions.question_text: If you make three holes at different heights on a plastic bottle filled with water, from which hole will the water come out with the greatest force?
questions.explanation_correct: Water comes out with the greatest force from the bottom hole because liquid pressure increases with depth. The bottom hole has the maximum depth of water above it, creating the highest pressure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The top hole (A) has the least water above it, so it has the least pressure. The middle hole (B) has moderate pressure. All holes do not have equal pressure (D). The bottom hole (C) has the most water above it, leading to the greatest pressure and force.

questions.question_text: Atmospheric pressure is caused by:

options.text: The weight of water in the oceans
The weight of air in the atmosphere

questions.explanation_correct: Atmospheric pressure is caused by the weight of the column of air in the atmosphere pressing down on the Earth's surface. The air has mass and exerts pressure on everything it surrounds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atmospheric pressure is not caused by ocean water (A), Earth's rotation (C), or solar heat (D). It is caused by the weight of air (B) in the atmosphere pressing down due to gravity.

questions.question_text: When you sip juice through a straw, the juice rises because:

options.text: The straw pushes the juice up
Gravity pulls the juice into your mouth
Atmospheric pressure pushes the juice up when air pressure inside the straw decreases

questions.explanation_correct: When you suck on a straw, you reduce the air pressure inside the straw. The atmospheric pressure acting on the surface of the juice in the glass is now greater, pushing the juice up through the straw into your mouth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The straw does not push juice (A). Gravity pulls the juice downward, not upward (B). The juice does not evaporate (D). The correct explanation involves atmospheric pressure (C) — sucking reduces air pressure inside the straw, and the higher atmospheric pressure outside pushes the juice up.

questions.question_text: Gravitational force is a contact force.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Gravitational force is a non-contact force. It acts between any two objects with mass without requiring physical contact. For example, the Earth's gravity pulls objects toward it without touching them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gravitational force acts at a distance without physical contact between objects. Therefore it is classified as a non-contact force, not a contact force.

questions.question_text: The pressure exerted by a liquid at a given depth is the same in all directions.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. At a given depth, a liquid exerts equal pressure in all directions — upward, downward, and sideways. This is because liquid particles are free to move and transmit pressure equally.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Liquids exert pressure equally in all directions at the same depth because their particles move freely and push equally in every direction.

questions.question_text: Forces that act on objects without physical contact are called ___ forces.
questions.explanation_correct: Non-contact forces act on objects from a distance without any physical contact. Examples include gravitational force, magnetic force, and electrostatic force.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'non-contact'. These forces can act from a distance, such as gravity pulling objects toward Earth without touching them.

questions.question_text: The pressure exerted by the weight of air in the atmosphere is called ___ pressure.
questions.explanation_correct: Atmospheric pressure is the pressure exerted by the weight of air in the atmosphere on the Earth's surface and all objects on it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'atmospheric'. The weight of the air column above us creates atmospheric pressure, which acts on everything around us.

questions.question_text: A goalkeeper catches a fast-moving ball and brings it to rest. The force applied by the goalkeeper:

options.text: Changes only the shape of the ball
Changes only the direction of the ball
Changes the state of motion of the ball
Has no effect on the ball

questions.explanation_correct: The goalkeeper's force changes the state of motion of the ball — the ball was moving and the force brings it to rest. This is a clear example of force changing the speed of an object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The force does not only change shape (A) or only direction (B). It clearly has an effect (D). The primary effect is changing the state of motion (C) — the moving ball is brought to rest.

questions.question_text: When you squeeze a sponge, the force applied causes a change in its:
questions.explanation_correct: When you squeeze a sponge, the applied force changes its shape. The sponge gets compressed. This demonstrates that force can change the shape of an object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Squeezing a sponge does not change its mass (A), weight (B), or colour (D). The force causes a change in its shape (C) — the sponge gets compressed.

questions.question_text: When a ball is thrown upward, it comes back down due to:
questions.explanation_correct: The ball comes back down due to gravitational force. The Earth's gravity pulls the ball back toward its centre. This is a non-contact force that acts on all objects near the Earth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Muscular force (A) is used to throw the ball, not bring it back. Friction (B) acts against motion but doesn't pull the ball down. Magnetic force (D) doesn't affect a ball. Gravity (C) is the force that pulls the ball back to Earth.

questions.question_text: A girl weighing 500 N is wearing shoes with a total contact area of 200 cm². If she stands on one foot, the pressure exerted on the ground becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: When she stands on one foot, the contact area is halved (100 cm² instead of 200 cm²). Since Pressure = Force / Area, and the force (her weight) remains the same, halving the area doubles the pressure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pressure does not become half (A), same (C), or zero (D). Standing on one foot reduces the area to half while the force stays the same. Since P = F/A, halving the area doubles (B) the pressure.

questions.question_text: A force of 200 N is applied on an area of 0.04 m². What is the pressure exerted?
questions.explanation_correct: Pressure = Force / Area = 200 N / 0.04 m² = 5000 Pa. The pressure exerted is 5000 Pascals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using P = F/A: 200 / 0.04 = 5000 Pa. The answer 50 Pa (A) and 500 Pa (B) come from incorrect division, and 8 Pa (D) comes from multiplying instead of dividing.

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs both contain non-contact forces?
questions.explanation_correct: Both magnetic force and gravitational force are non-contact forces — they act on objects from a distance without physical contact.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Muscular force and friction (A) are both contact forces. Friction (C) is a contact force. Normal force (D) is a contact force. Only option B has both forces as non-contact forces.

questions.question_text: Two forces act on an object in opposite directions. The object will move in the direction of the:

options.text: Neither direction; it will remain stationary

questions.explanation_correct: When two forces act in opposite directions, the net force is in the direction of the larger force. The object will move in the direction of the resultant (net) force, which is the direction of the larger force.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The object does not move toward the smaller force (A). It remains stationary only if the forces are equal (C). It does not move perpendicular (D). The net force is in the direction of the larger force (B).

questions.question_text: A rubber suction cup sticks to a smooth wall because:

options.text: Atmospheric pressure pushes it against the wall after air is removed

questions.explanation_correct: When a suction cup is pressed against a wall, air is pushed out from between the cup and the wall. The atmospheric pressure on the outside is now greater than the reduced pressure inside, pushing the cup firmly against the wall.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gravity (A) pulls objects downward, not against walls. The wall does not attract the cup (B). The cup is not magnetic (D). The correct explanation involves atmospheric pressure (C) pushing the cup after air is expelled.

questions.question_text: A diver experiences greater pressure at a depth of 20 m compared to 5 m because:

options.text: Water becomes denser at greater depth
The weight of water above is greater at 20 m
The diver is heavier at 20 m
Atmospheric pressure increases at greater depth

questions.explanation_correct: At 20 m depth, there is a larger column of water above the diver, which means greater weight of water pressing down. This results in higher pressure at greater depths.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water does not become significantly denser at moderate depths (A). The diver's weight doesn't change (C). Atmospheric pressure acts at the surface but liquid pressure increases with depth due to the weight of water above (B), not atmospheric pressure increasing (D).

questions.question_text: Camels have broad flat feet so that:

options.text: They can run faster on sand
Their feet do not sink into soft sand due to reduced pressure
They look different from other animals
They can hold more water in their feet

questions.explanation_correct: Camels have broad flat feet to increase the contact area with the sand. Since Pressure = Force / Area, a larger area reduces the pressure exerted on the sand, preventing their feet from sinking.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Broad feet do not help with running speed (A), appearance (C), or water storage (D). The broad feet spread the camel's weight over a larger area (B), reducing pressure on the soft sand.

questions.question_text: When a sealed tin can containing some water is heated and then cooled quickly by pouring cold water over it, the can gets crushed. This happens because:

options.text: Steam condenses inside, reducing pressure; atmospheric pressure crushes the can
Water enters the can and crushes it
The cold water applies force on the can

questions.explanation_correct: When the can is heated, steam replaces air inside. When cooled, the steam condenses, creating a partial vacuum (low pressure) inside the can. The atmospheric pressure outside is now much greater and crushes the can inward.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cold water does not weaken metal significantly (A). Water does not enter and crush the can (C). The small amount of cold water poured cannot crush a metal can (D). The can is crushed because atmospheric pressure outside exceeds the reduced pressure inside after steam condenses (B).

questions.question_text: Identify the situation where the applied force does NOT change the state of motion of the object:
questions.explanation_correct: When you push a wall, the wall does not move because the wall exerts an equal and opposite reaction force. The state of motion remains unchanged. In all other cases, the force causes the object to move.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kicking a ball (B), pulling a cart (C), and throwing a stone (D) all change the state of motion. But pushing a wall (A) does not change the wall's state of motion because it does not move.

questions.question_text: We do not feel atmospheric pressure because the pressure inside our body is equal to the atmospheric pressure outside.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The pressure of air inside our body (in our lungs, blood vessels, etc.) balances the atmospheric pressure outside. Because these pressures are equal, we do not feel the enormous atmospheric pressure acting on us.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The reason we don't collapse under atmospheric pressure is that the pressure inside our body equals the atmospheric pressure outside, creating a balance.

questions.question_text: If the area of contact is doubled while the force remains the same, the pressure will also double.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Since Pressure = Force / Area, if the area is doubled with the same force, the pressure is halved, not doubled. Pressure is inversely proportional to area.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false because pressure and area are inversely related. Doubling the area with the same force halves the pressure, not doubles it.

questions.question_text: Liquid pressure increases with ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Liquid pressure increases with depth because as we go deeper, the weight of the liquid column above increases, exerting more force per unit area.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'depth'. The deeper you go in a liquid, the more liquid is above you, which means greater weight pressing down and therefore greater pressure.

questions.question_text: The net force on an object when two equal forces act in opposite directions is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: When two equal forces act in opposite directions, they cancel each other out, resulting in a net force of zero. These are called balanced forces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'zero'. Equal forces in opposite directions cancel each other, producing zero net force. The object remains in its current state of motion.

questions.question_text: Why does water flow out faster from a hole at the bottom of a bucket than from a hole near the top?

options.text: Because the bucket is thinner at the bottom
Because the water pressure is greater at the bottom
Because gravity is stronger at the bottom of the bucket
Because water is heavier at the bottom

questions.explanation_correct: Water flows out faster from the bottom hole because the pressure in a liquid increases with depth. The bottom hole has more water above it, creating greater pressure that pushes the water out with more force.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The bucket thickness (A) is not the reason. Gravity is essentially the same at the top and bottom of a bucket (C). Water density doesn't change with depth in a bucket (D). The greater water pressure at the bottom (B) is the correct explanation.

questions.question_text: At higher altitudes, atmospheric pressure:

options.text: Increases because we are closer to the sun
Decreases because the column of air above is shorter

questions.explanation_correct: At higher altitudes, atmospheric pressure decreases because there is a shorter column of air above. Less air means less weight pressing down, resulting in lower atmospheric pressure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Proximity to the sun (A) does not cause higher pressure. Pressure does not remain the same (C) at different altitudes. Air speed (D) is not the primary factor. The shorter air column at higher altitudes (B) means less weight and therefore lower pressure.

questions.question_text: Which of the following activities involves both contact and non-contact forces?

options.text: Writing with a pen on paper
A ball thrown upward slowing down and falling back
Pushing a box across the floor

questions.explanation_correct: When a ball is thrown upward, the throwing involves muscular force (contact) and the ball slowing down and falling involves gravity (non-contact) and air friction (contact). This activity involves both types of forces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Writing (A) mainly involves contact forces. Magnets (C) involve non-contact forces. Pushing a box (D) mainly involves contact forces. Only option B clearly involves both contact (throwing) and non-contact (gravity) forces.

questions.question_text: A rectangular block can rest on three different faces with areas 10 cm², 20 cm², and 40 cm². On which face will it exert the least pressure on the table?

options.text: Pressure is the same on all faces

questions.explanation_correct: The block exerts the least pressure when resting on the 40 cm² face because it has the largest area. Since Pressure = Force / Area and the force (weight) is constant, the larger the area, the lower the pressure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pressure is not the same on all faces (D). The 10 cm² face (A) gives the highest pressure. The 20 cm² face (B) gives moderate pressure. The 40 cm² face (C) has the largest area and therefore the least pressure.

questions.question_text: A liquid is poured into containers of different shapes but to the same height. The pressure at the bottom of each container is:
questions.explanation_correct: The pressure at the bottom depends only on the height (depth) of the liquid, not on the shape or width of the container. Since the liquid is at the same height in all containers, the pressure at the bottom is the same in all of them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Width (A, B) does not affect pressure at the bottom. Since all containers have the same liquid height, the pressure is the same (C). The containers are filled to the same height, so option D is not relevant.
